Subject: FYI/ Heritrix ARC naming, header conventions due for update

As part of a pending RFE, Heritrix's conventions for naming and
formatting the 'version-block' header record of ARCs is due to
change this week. This is a heads-up and invitation to comment
on the planned changes:

The RFE:

http://sourceforge.net/tracker/index.php?func=detail&aid=936684&group_id=73833&atid=539102

An explanation:

For long-term inventory purposes, it is important ARCs
have names that are descriptive and highly likely to be
unique, and that they feature a header explaining the
software that was used and ideally the 'crawl'/purpose
that drove their collection. Current conventions don't
always meet this need, though it's possible, within the
existing formats.

NAMES:

Currently, Heritrix ARC names are of the form:

[operator-given-name][12-digit-timestamp]-[series#].arc.gz

We plan to change them to:

[operator-given-name]-[series#-padded-to-5-digits]-[12-digit-timestamp]-[Base32-of-crawler-IP].arc.gz

By moving the series nmber before the timestamp, it is
easier for people to work with shell-completion to
enter a specific filename. But padding the series# to 5
digits, sort order is preserved even when series
numbers gain significant digits, up to 100,000 items
(10TB at 100MB/arc).

By adding the crawl machine IP at the end uniqueness is
nearly guaranteed. By representing the IP in Base32 the
machine name will be much like a radio callsign -- more
compact than dotted-decimal or hex, more memorable than
32-bit decimal number. IP is preferred to machine name
as DNS info is more volatile and manipulable.

An ARC name under the new system might look like:

   CONGRESS-00007-20040420133907-FG71E2B.arc.gz

HEADERS:

Currently, Heritrix ARC header records are no different
than classic Alexa ARC headers; only dates and ARC names
distinguish current Heritrix crawls from Alexa crawls.

That header record should be extended with some means
of capturing, at the operator's option, the following
fields and more...

(1) software & version used
(2) operator/contact name
(3) 'user-agent' header used
(4) 'from' header used
(5) operator note about purpose of crawl
(6) crawl machine DNS name
(7) reference to settings in effect at time of crawl
(perhaps hash of settings file/bundle?)
(8) etc.

We plan to add a block of arbitrary XML after the existing
two lines of ARC metdata. Thus the definition of the <version_block>
from http://www.archive.org/web/researcher/ArcFileFormat.php would
become:

version-block == filedesc://<path><sp><version specific data><sp><length><nl>
<version-number><sp><reserved><sp><origin-code><nl>
<URL-record-definition><nl>
<xml-metadata><nl>
<nl>

xml-metadata == well-formed XML, drawing elements from a to-be-defined
namespace/schema

The version number and reserved fields would remain "1 0" as this
is currently believed to be a backward-compatible change with
existing ARC-scanning software. The organizational <origin-code>
would be changeable through the Heritrix interface, and convention
would be encouraged where the format is "Organization/Purpose".

An ARC version-block would look like the following under the new
conventions:

filedesc://CONGRESS-00007-20040420133907-FG71E.arc.gz 0.0.0.0 20040420133907 text/plain 410
1 0 InternetArchive/Congress
URL IP-address Archive-date Content-type Archive-length
<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<arc-header xmlns="http://www.archive.org/xmlns/arc-header">
   <organization>InternetArchive</organization>
   <software>Heritrix/0.7.1</software>
   <user-agent>os-heritrix/0.7.1 (http://crawler.archive.org)</user-agent>
   <operator>gojomo/at/archive</operator>
   <purpose>monthly crawl of US Congress websites for Library of Congress</purpose>
   <!-- etc -->
</arc-header>

- Gordon @ IA
